name: Joaquim
bio:
**Joaquim Carvalho Cruz**  (born March 12, 1963) is a former  [Brazilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil "Brazil")  middle-distance runner, winner of the 800 meters at the  [1984 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1984_Summer_Olympics "1984 Summer Olympics"). He is one of only five men to run the  [800 metres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/800_metres "800 metres")  in less than 1 minute, 42 seconds.

## Biography

Cruz was born in  [Taguatinga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taguatinga,_Federal_District "Taguatinga, Federal District"),  [Distrito Federal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_District_(Brazil) "Federal District (Brazil)"). As the son of a steel worker, he began running as a 13-year-old, and soon showed astonishing talent as a junior. At the age of only 15 his personal best over 800 m stood at 1:51 min. After setting a junior  [world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record "World record")  of 1:44.3 min in 1981, he received a scholarship for the  [University of Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Oregon "University of Oregon")  in 1983. The move immediately paid off, and Cruz won the  [NCAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Collegiate_Athletic_Association "National Collegiate Athletic Association")  championships over 800 m that same year. He also competed in the  [inaugural World Championships](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1983_World_Championships_in_Athletics "1983 World Championships in Athletics")  in 1983, winning the bronze.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-iaaf-2)

The following year, Cruz became one of only a handful of people to win the 800/1500 m double at the 1984 NCAA Track & Field Championships (a feat that would not be repeated for another 26 years until another Oregon Duck,  [Andrew Wheating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Wheating "Andrew Wheating"), turned the trick in 2010). Cruz is the co-holder of  [University of Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Oregon "University of Oregon")  1,500 m school record of 3:36.48 along with A.J. Acosta.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-3)  Later that summer, he ran a time of 2:14.09 min over 1000 m in  [Nice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nice "Nice")  which is still the current  [South American record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_South_American_records_in_athletics "List of South American records in athletics")  over that distance.

The 1984 Olympic Games were held in  [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), and Cruz was considered to be one of the 800 m favorites, along with  [world record](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_record "World record")  holder  [Sebastian Coe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sebastian_Coe "Sebastian Coe")  of Britain. In the last turn of the 800 meter final, Cruz started a sprint from second place and took the lead, never losing it. He crossed the line in 1:43.00, breaking  [Alberto Juantorena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberto_Juantorena "Alberto Juantorena")'s Olympic Record and making him the first Brazilian Olympic track and field gold medalist since  [triple jumper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_jump "Triple jump")  [Adhemar Ferreira da Silva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adhemar_Ferreira_da_Silva "Adhemar Ferreira da Silva")  won both in  [1952](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 1952 Summer Olympics")  and  [1956](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athletics_at_the_1956_Summer_Olympics "Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)

Later that week, after winning his first round heat of the Olympic 1500 m, Cruz, due to a cold, did not start in the semi-finals, which caused quite a stir among the Brazilians, who thought he didn't want to represent his country in an event in which his chances of winning were smaller. Cruz eventually recovered from his cold and had a remarkable five-day stretch of racing a few weeks after the Olympic Games. First, he ran a new Brazilian 800 m record of 1:42.34 at the Weltklasse meet in Zurich, becoming only the second runner in history to break 1:43. Two days later he ran a 1:42.41 at the  [Memorial Van Damme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_Van_Damme "Memorial Van Damme")  meet in  [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), and then two days after that, at a meeting in  [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"), Cruz ran the second fastest 800 meters in history, his time of 1:41.77 was only four hundredths of a second outside of Coe's world record. He is the fifth fastest athlete in the history of the event.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-4)  By the end of the year, he was the NCAA champion, the Olympic champion, undefeated in all seven of his 800-meter finals, had run the 2nd, 4th, 5th, and 6th fastest 800 meter times in history, and easily ranked as #1 in the world for 800 meters in 1984 by  [Track & Field News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_%26_Field_News "Track & Field News")  magazine.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)

In 1985 Cruz confirmed the excellent results of the previous year by winning six of his eight 800 meter races, the last three of which were won under 1:43: 1:42.98 at ISTAF, 1:42.53 in Cologne (beating Sebastian Coe), and 1:42.49 in Koblenz. His record was good enough to earn him a World #1 ranking by  _Track & Field News_  magazine for the second year in a row. He also ran the world's 3rd fastest 1,000 meter time for 1985, a 2:15.11. In the following two years he struggled with injuries and raced little, though he did manage to win the gold medal in the 1,500 meters at the  [1987 Pan American Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1987_Pan_American_Games "1987 Pan American Games"), defeating both  [Jim Spivey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Spivey "Jim Spivey")  (who within the next month would win a bronze medal at the World Championships) and American mile record holder  [Steve Scott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Scott_(athlete) "Steve Scott (athlete)").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)

At the  [1988 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics"), Cruz appeared to be on his way to retain his Olympic 800 m title when he was passed by  [Kenyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenya "Kenya")  runner  [Paul Ereng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Ereng "Paul Ereng"), leaving Cruz with the silver medal. Troubled by  [Achilles' tendon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles%27_tendon "Achilles' tendon")  injuries, Cruz was never again able to reach the international top level. In 1993, he tried to make a comeback and started over 1500 m at various Grand Prix races in Europe but failed to make a major impact. His last victory of significance came in the 1500 meters at the  [1995 Pan American Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_Pan_American_Games "1995 Pan American Games"). One year later, taking part at his third Olympics at the  [1996 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics "1996 Summer Olympics"), Cruz was the Brazilian flag-bearer and ran the 1500 meters without reaching the finals.[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-sr-1)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-5)

Cruz was a torchbearer and lit the flame cauldron at the  [2007 Pan American Games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pan_American_Games "2007 Pan American Games")  in  [Rio de Janeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"), on July 13, 2007. After retiring from competitions he became a running coach at the Olympic Training Center in  [Chula Vista, California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chula_Vista,_California "Chula Vista, California"). He guides[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-6)  Lea Wallace,  [David Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Brown_(parathlete) "David Brown (parathlete)")  and  [Shaquille Vance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaquille_Vance "Shaquille Vance"), among others.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-brown-7)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquim_Cruz#cite_note-vance-8)
